body:
I think the first question about inputs has to do with #133 which I've provided a solution for in the issue itself. 

What do you mean by "support for DataFrame"? Basically pandas dataframe is a wrapper for numpy arrays, so you can just `df.y.values` to get the array. Or if you want to take more than one column then e.g. `df.iloc[:,:12].values`. Unless I'm missing something, this would do it. What do you think?
By support I mean I can input a list of data frames into the Scan function like so `[df1, df2, df3]` and talos should call `.values` when it detects data frame.
You could do it now in the form of [df1.values, df2.values, df3.values] which is exactly the same as [df1, df2, df3] with support for dataframe :)

Yes. I'm feeding a list of numpy arrays now not dataframe. I just think it would be good if talos is flexible to accept both types of inputs.
Anyway, I tried feeding the list of inputs and here's the output:
```python
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-61-5f0c25e20311> in <module>()
      3 }
      4 h = ta.Scan(X_train_keras, y_train.values, params, build_deep_model, val_split=0.2,
----> 5             dataset_name='em-wave-pos', experiment_no='1')

c:\users\admin\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\talos\scan\Scan.py in __init__(self, x, y, params, model, dataset_name, experiment_no, x_val, y_val, val_split, shuffle, round_limit, grid_downsample, random_method, seed, search_method, reduction_method, reduction_interval, reduction_window, reduction_threshold, reduction_metric, reduce_loss, last_epoch_value, clear_tf_session, disable_progress_bar, print_params, debug)
    161         # input parameters section ends
    162 
--> 163         self._null = self.runtime()
    164 
    165     def runtime(self):

c:\users\admin\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\talos\scan\Scan.py in runtime(self)
    165     def runtime(self):
    166 
--> 167         self = scan_prepare(self)
    168         self = scan_run(self)

c:\users\admin\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\talos\scan\scan_prepare.py in scan_prepare(self)
     57     # create the data asset
     58     self.y_max = self.y.max()
---> 59     self = validation_split(self)
     60     self.shape = classify(self.y)
     61     self.last_neuron = last_neuron(self)

c:\users\admin\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\talos\utils\validation_split.py in validation_split(self)
     16     else:
     17         if self.shuffle:
---> 18             random_shuffle(self)
     19 
     20         limit = int(len(self.x) * (1 - self.val_split))

c:\users\admin\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\talos\utils\validation_split.py in random_shuffle(self)
     40     np.random.shuffle(random_index)
     41 
---> 42     self.x = self.x[random_index]
     43     self.y = self.y[random_index]
     44 

TypeError: only integer scalar arrays can be converted to a scalar index
```
This is the code:
```python
params = {
    
}
h = ta.Scan(X_train_keras, y_train.values, params, build_deep_model, val_split=0.2,
            dataset_name='em-wave-pos', experiment_no='1')
```
`X_train_keras` is a list containing 4 numpy arrays. What is the issue here? I've already updated to v0.4.4

Can you input a list of 4 numpy arrays to a Keras model? Have you tried that what you are trying to do with Talos works with a Keras model as a standalone?

Also as a small pointer check the parameter order for Scan() as it changed for 0.4.4. and just in case it's better to use argument names as well the values (e.g. val_split=0.2 good, and params not good).

It works with standalone keras model. The keras accepts 4 numpy arrays fine.
Also the parameter is correct, I also put named parameter and it still doesn't work.

What is your use-case for passing a list of 2d-arrays as opposed to passing a single 3d-array or I think better question is what are you trying to achieve by passing arrays in a list into the model. 

Are the four arrays all of the same shape, and what is the shape? 

What is the error message you are getting now (it can't be the same as in 0.4.3 as the functionality is completely changed regarding functional models).

Here's the shape of each array. 3 of them are 3D but one of them is 2D:
```
    input_x = keras.Input(shape=(200,1), name='x')
    input_y = keras.Input(shape=(200,1), name='y')
    input_z = keras.Input(shape=(200,1), name='z')
    input_q = keras.Input(shape=(4,), name='q')
```
So you cannot just pass a single array because they vary in size. Even if their size are equal, it's still a hack not a solution to pass in an array instead of a list.
The error above is from version 0.4.4 as I have already printed the version to the notebook in the same session and it said 0.4.4.

I can make this kinda work by sending a numpy array of shape (None, 604) into the Scan function instead of sending the list. And then I would split it into a list of 4 arrays later inside the model function. But that means the data is being splitted every single time the model function is called. So I would like to send a preprocessed list of splitted data instead.

Here's the model function:
```python
# build and train then return the history and the model
def build_deep_model(X_train, y_train, X_val, y_val, params):
#     X_train_keras = wave_df_to_keras_inputs(X_train)
#     X_val_keras = wave_df_to_keras_inputs(X_val)
    X_train_keras = X_train
    X_val_keras = X_val
    print(X_val_keras)
    input_x = keras.Input(shape=(200,1), name='x')
    input_y = keras.Input(shape=(200,1), name='y')
    input_z = keras.Input(shape=(200,1), name='z')
    input_q = keras.Input(shape=(4,), name='q')
    def compute_wave_features(x, name=None):
        x = keras.layers.Conv1D(32, 5, strides=2, padding='same', activation='relu')(x)
        x = keras.layers.Conv1D(32, 5, strides=2, padding='same', activation='relu')(x)
        x = keras.layers.Conv1D(32, 5, strides=2, padding='same', activation='relu')(x)
        x = keras.layers.Conv1D(32, 5, strides=2, padding='valid', activation='relu')(x)
        x = keras.layers.Flatten()(x)
        x = keras.layers.Dense(64, activation='relu', name=name)(x)
        return x
    feature_x = compute_wave_features(input_x, 'feature_x')
    feature_y = compute_wave_features(input_y, 'feature_y')
    feature_z = compute_wave_features(input_z, 'feature_z')
    features = keras.layers.Concatenate()([feature_x, feature_y, feature_z, input_q])
    features = keras.layers.Dense(32, activation='relu')(features)
    readout = keras.layers.Dense(y_train.shape[1], activation='linear', name='readout')(features)
    deep_model = keras.models.Model(inputs=[input_x, input_y, input_z, input_q], outputs=readout)
    deep_model.compile('adam', loss='mse', metrics=['mae', r2_keras])
#     deep_model.summary()

    callbacks = [
        keras.callbacks.EarlyStopping(patience=3)
    ]
    history = deep_model.fit(X_train_keras, y_train, epochs=500, validation_data=[X_val_keras, y_val], callbacks=callbacks, verbose=2)
    best_r2 = np.max(history.history['val_r2_keras'])
    epochs = history.epoch[-1] + 1
    print("Best val_r2_keras score:", best_r2, 'Epochs:', epochs)
    return history, deep_model
```
I think the error occur before the model function is being called.

Here's how I think the error occurs:
When I give Scan() a list of numpy arrays, and then Scan() will need to split the data into train and validation right?
But a list cannot be splitted easily compared to an array. So I think you need to investigate how you do split when a list is being fed.

That's right, I can see now the error message is from the latest version. What happens there is that Talos tries to perform validation split, but is unable to do it as the input is a list with 4 arrays, so the approach you mention makes sense here. As long as you do the split on numpy array level, this should not make much difference in terms of performance. 

To have a better understanding of your purpose for doing things in this way, what are the four arrays inside the list (what do they represent) and what is that you are trying to predict?

Well, splitting arrays inside a list would be very simple in the sense of treating each array separately. But first I need to understand what is that we're trying to do here (as this is the first time I come across the need to pass arrays inside a list into a single model).

There are many scenarios where passing a list is important.
Suppose you have a problem of predicting the profession of a person in the picture.
You have picture as the input and luckily, you also have the age and gender of the person along with the picture.
You now need to send 3 information, image, age, and gender to keras. Keras then need to classify whether the person is a programmer or a singer.
And the information along with the image is very important, if you are male, you are more likely to be a programmer.
You cannot just squeeze them into one array because the image is an array but age and gender are just a single number. And it doesn't make sense to apply Convolution to age and gender.

FYI, my problem is about predicting a position of an electromagnetic wave receiver.
The wave has 3 axis, XYZ and I also have another device (an IMU) that measures the orientation of the receiver.

Thanks for explaining that. Let's use your stated example as a base of reference to make sure we are talking about the same things. 

When you say "each information is different type" what do you mean by this? From the standpoint of a Keras model, there is no difference between age and gender for example. Between the image data and age/gender do you see some other difference in type than dimensionality?

By the way, once we resolve your case, I think it will make sense to create a notebook example that deals with a typical wave positional prediction case. Generally speaking the optimal Keras way of doing something is far simpler than what the user thinks.

The difference is also about the abstraction level.
For example, pixel is a low-level but for gender it's quite high level.
This means you can feed the gender at a later layer.

E.g. the image will be convolved and about 2 layers later then you concatenate with gender feature, then connect to dense layer. 

Keras also has example about multi-inputs so you can take a look at it. We need list of inputs to feed to the model. https://keras.io/getting-started/functional-api-guide/

issue.title: AttributeError: 'Model' object has no attribute 'predict_classes'

repository.name: talos
repository.description: Hyperparameter Optimization for TensorFlow, Keras and PyTorch

issue.body:
- [x] I'm up-to-date with the latest release:
    
      pip install -U talos


- [x] I've confirmed that my Keras model works outside of Talos.

I have an error when I run scan. I am suspecting that it's because my model is not Sequential but talos expects it to be Sequential. And it's because my input is a list of numpy arrays, not a numpy array.

Here is the model code (it works and run until the last line because I saw it printed "Best val_r2_keras score"):
```python
# build and train then return the history and the model
def build_deep_model(X_train, y_train, X_val, y_val, params):
    X_train_keras = wave_df_to_keras_inputs(X_train) # this function converts array of shape (?, 604) to a list of 4 numpy arrays of shape (?,200,1), (?,200,1), (?,200,1), and (?,4)
    X_val_keras = wave_df_to_keras_inputs(X_val)
    input_x = keras.Input(shape=(200,1), name='x')
    input_y = keras.Input(shape=(200,1), name='y')
    input_z = keras.Input(shape=(200,1), name='z')
    input_q = keras.Input(shape=(4,), name='q')
    def compute_wave_features(x, name=None):
        x = keras.layers.Conv1D(32, 5, strides=2, padding='same', activation='relu')(x)
        x = keras.layers.Conv1D(32, 5, strides=2, padding='same', activation='relu')(x)
        x = keras.layers.Conv1D(32, 5, strides=2, padding='same', activation='relu')(x)
        x = keras.layers.Conv1D(32, 5, strides=2, padding='valid', activation='relu')(x)
        x = keras.layers.Flatten()(x)
        x = keras.layers.Dense(64, activation='relu', name=name)(x)
        return x
    feature_x = compute_wave_features(input_x, 'feature_x')
    feature_y = compute_wave_features(input_y, 'feature_y')
    feature_z = compute_wave_features(input_z, 'feature_z')
    features = keras.layers.Concatenate()([feature_x, feature_y, feature_z, input_q])
    features = keras.layers.Dense(32, activation='relu')(features)
    readout = keras.layers.Dense(y_train.shape[1], activation='linear', name='readout')(features)
    deep_model = keras.models.Model(inputs=[input_x, input_y, input_z, input_q], outputs=readout)
    deep_model.compile('adam', loss='mse', metrics=['mae', r2_keras])
    deep_model.summary()

    callbacks = [
        keras.callbacks.EarlyStopping(patience=3)
    ]
    history = deep_model.fit(X_train_keras, y_train, epochs=500, validation_data=[X_val_keras, y_val], callbacks=callbacks, verbose=2)
    best_r2 = np.max(history.history['val_r2_keras'])
    epochs = history.epoch[-1] + 1
    print("Best val_r2_keras score:", best_r2, 'Epochs:', epochs)
    return history, deep_model
```

Here is the code that produces the error (no params yet):
```python
params = {
    
}
h = ta.Scan(X_train.values, y_train.values, params, build_deep_model, val_split=0.2, dataset_name='em-wave-pos', experiment_no='1')
```

Here is the output:

```python

---> 47     self._val_score = get_score(self)

     36         # all other cases
     37         else:
---> 38             y_pred = self.keras_model.predict_classes(self.x_val)
     39 
     40         return Performance(y_pred, self.y_val, self.shape, self.y_max).result

AttributeError: 'Model' object has no attribute 'predict_classes'
```

I read a [stackoverflow post](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44806125/attributeerror-model-object-has-no-attribute-predict-classes) about this error and they said it's because `predict_classes` only exist in `Sequential` model. 

I'm also confused because I'm building a regressor not a classifier, why is talos trying to predict classes?

How do I fix this issue?

body:
Another problem when I Evaluate:
```python
e = ta.Evaluate(h)
e.evaluate(X_train.values, y_train.values, metric='val_r2_keras')
```
I use the exact same way of inputting the data. That is feeding the array but now the model expects the list.
```python
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-88-3c803f58efff> in <module>()

----> 2 e.evaluate(X_train.values, y_train.values, metric='val_loss')

     38         for i in range(folds):
---> 39             y_pred = model.predict(kx[i]) >= 0.5
     40             scores = f1_score(y_pred, ky[i], average=average)
     41             out.append(scores * 100)

   1148         # Validate user data.
-> 1149         x, _, _ = self._standardize_user_data(x)
   1150         if self.stateful:
   1151             if x[0].shape[0] > batch_size and x[0].shape[0] % batch_size != 0:

c:\users\admin\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\keras\engine\training.py in _standardize_user_data(self, x, y, sample_weight, class_weight, check_array_lengths, batch_size)
    749             feed_input_shapes,
    750             check_batch_axis=False,  # Don't enforce the batch size.
--> 751             exception_prefix='input')
    752 
    753         if y is not None:

c:\users\admin\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\keras\engine\training_utils.py in standardize_input_data(data, names, shapes, check_batch_axis, exception_prefix)

    101                 'but instead got the following list of ' +
--> 102                 str(len(data)) + ' arrays: ' + str(data)[:200] + '...')
    103         elif len(names) > 1:
    104             raise ValueError(

ValueError: Error when checking model input: the list of Numpy arrays that you are passing to your model is not the size the model expected. Expected to see 4 array(s), but instead got the following list of 1 arrays: [array([[-0.01658162, -0.88896018, -1.08376316, ...,  0.28      ,
        -0.66      ,  0.61      ],
       [ 0.20363044, -2.47279311, -3.06567174, ...,  0.28      ,
        -0.66      ,  0.61      ],...
```

Got it. This is an interesting approach you are articulating, and it sounds relevant to consider. Would it be possible for you to produce the simplest possible example of Keras model and dummy dataset so I can play around with the wave position prediction task. Without any consideration to Talos, just something that works in Keras. I could try and do it later today. Will try a couple of things to make sure I'm on the same page with you on this, and then we could discuss next steps.

And when I do feed it the list the model said it cannot do KFold (maybe it's trying to split something?):
```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-89-4e43c53b25f9> in <module>()
      1 e = ta.Evaluate(h)
----> 2 e.evaluate(X_train_keras, y_train.values, metric='val_r2_keras')

c:\users\admin\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\talos\commands\evaluate.py in evaluate(self, x, y, model_id, folds, shuffle, average, metric, asc)
     34         model = activate_model(self.scan_object, model_id)
     35 
---> 36         kx, ky = kfold(x, y, folds, shuffle)
     37 
     38         for i in range(folds):

c:\users\admin\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\talos\utils\validation_split.py in kfold(x, y, folds, shuffled)
     47 
     48     if shuffled is True:
---> 49         x, y = shuffle(x, y)
     50 
     51     out_x = []

c:\users\admin\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\wrangle\shuffle.py in shuffle(x, y)
      9     random.shuffle(random_index)
     10 
---> 11     x = x[random_index]
     12     y = y[random_index]
     13 

TypeError: only integer scalar arrays can be converted to a scalar index
```
Yes, here we are using the same splitting function as in the Scan() so you will have the same error in both.

OK. Another quetsion, after I do the Scan(), how do I access the trained model other than Deploying and Restoring from disk?
I want to evaluate the model myself.
Is there something I can do like `scan.get_best_model().predict(stuff)`?

You could use `best_model()` to identify the id of the best model, and then `model = activate_model(id)` and finally `model.predict(x)`.

You can access it by: 

`from talos.utils.best_model import best_model, activate_model`

All the models are stored in saved_models in the Scan() object and weights in saved_weights, so you could also hand pick any based on analyzing the results and then activate it. 

If you want to do it in a one-liner, you can: 

`activate_model(scan_object, best_model(scan_object, 'val_acc', False)).predict(X)`

issue.title: add "predict with best model" to Scan object

repository.name: talos
repository.description: Hyperparameter Optimization for TensorFlow, Keras and PyTorch

issue.body: The idea came up in #132 and some other issues previously. This seems to be a simple, yet highly useful addition to the Scan object.

body:
OK. I've written a working example for you. Here's the code and some of the data you can play with:
https://gist.github.com/off99555/cfd94d91d24088c3ed5b9ba79b11e7af
https://mega.nz/#F!A5NwHKjK!mgtkQbWtdHcIVoQdezrKzA

Thanks, I checked it and everything seems to be in place. I'm working on something else at the moment, but most likely later this evening would spend sometime learning about this problem. 

Very cool prediction problem you are working on.

@off99555 I've made the changes on my local branch to support the case where input is a list of arrays. Because this is in the mainline of the program, it will take a little bit time before it will make its way to production, but I think I should be able to have it in daily-dev in the next few days (if not already later today). Thanks for making the case.
